title: Diffuse White Matter Disease
scope: ** Evaluation and management of diffuse white matter changes found on neuroimaging, including systematic differential diagnosis approach (vascular, inflammatory, infectious, metabolic, genetic, toxic), workup prioritization by clinical context, and management across care settings. Excludes focal single-lesion pathology and acute stroke as primary diagnosis but includes in differential. Covers both incidental findings and symptomatic presentations.

Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Infection screening; anemia as contributor to cognitive symptoms; leukocytosis suggesting inflammatory or infectious etiology
Renal function (uremic leukoencephalopathy); hepatic function (hepatic leukoencephalopathy); electrolytes; glucose
Diabetes is leading vascular risk factor for CSVD and white matter disease; assess glycemic control
Dyslipidemia contributes to cerebral small vessel disease and accelerates white matter injury
Hypothyroidism causes reversible white matter changes and cognitive impairment
B12 deficiency causes white matter disease (subacute combined degeneration) and is treatable
Elevated in B12 deficiency even when serum B12 borderline normal; more sensitive than B12 alone
Folate deficiency contributes to hyperhomocysteinemia and white matter injury
Elevated homocysteine associated with accelerated white matter disease and cognitive decline; treatable with B vitamins
Inflammatory markers; elevated in vasculitis, CNS infection, autoimmune conditions; baseline for inflammatory etiologies
Neurosyphilis causes diffuse white matter changes; treatable; must screen in all unexplained leukoencephalopathy
HIV-associated leukoencephalopathy; PML risk; treatable; screen all patients with unexplained WMD
Renal disease screening; proteinuria associated with CSVD; drug screening context

Extended Labs.rationale: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) causes CNS vasculitis and white matter disease
Specific for SLE; elevated in lupus cerebritis/CNS lupus
Low complement supports active SLE or other complement-consuming processes

Extended Labs.item: Antiphospholipid antibodies (anticardiolipin, anti-beta-2 glycoprotein, lupus anticoagulant)
Extended Labs.rationale: Antiphospholipid syndrome causes thrombotic vasculopathy and white matter disease; treatable with anticoagulation
Primary CNS vasculitis and systemic vasculitis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis, microscopic polyangiitis)
Neurosarcoidosis causes white matter lesions; elevated ACE supportive but not diagnostic
Neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder can present with extensive white matter changes
MOG antibody-associated disease with diffuse white matter involvement; distinct from MS and NMOSD
Wilson disease (low copper/ceruloplasmin) causes white matter injury; copper deficiency myelopathy mimics B12 deficiency
Zinc excess causes copper deficiency and myelopathy/leukoencephalopathy
Metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD); deficient enzyme activity; adult-onset form presents with behavioral/cognitive changes and white matter disease
Krabbe disease (globoid cell leukodystrophy); rare adult-onset form
Mitochondrial disease causes white matter injury with elevated lactate; MELAS, Leigh syndrome
Toxic leukoencephalopathy from heroin inhalation ("chasing the dragon"), toluene, methanol, carbon monoxide
Carbon monoxide poisoning causes delayed white matter injury; must check if any exposure concern

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) if immunocompromised; see LP section
Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy; young onset, migraine, mood changes, lacunar strokes
Cerebral autosomal recessive arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy; alopecia, spondylosis in young adults
Mitochondrial leukoencephalopathy (MELAS, Leigh syndrome, Kearns-Sayre); maternal inheritance pattern
Confirmatory for X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy if VLCFA elevated
Screening for lysosomal storage disorders (Fabry, MLD, Krabbe) in young-onset unexplained leukoencephalopathy
Fabry disease; small vessel disease, white matter changes, stroke in young adults; X-linked
Elevated in mitochondrial disease and some infections; complement serum lactate
Undiagnosed genetic leukoencephalopathy after targeted testing negative; emerging standard for adult-onset leukodystrophies
Last resort for undiagnosed progressive white matter disease after non-invasive workup exhausted

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in venous sinus thrombosis, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, meningitis
Pleocytosis indicates inflammatory/infectious process; lymphocytic predominance in MS, viral, sarcoid; neutrophilic in bacterial
Elevated in MS, GBS, vasculitis, infection, malignancy
Low CSF/serum ratio in bacterial infection, carcinomatous meningitis, fungal infection, sarcoidosis
Positive in MS (present in CSF but not serum); also positive in neurosyphilis, SSPE, sarcoidosis
Intrathecal IgG synthesis supports MS; elevated in other inflammatory conditions
CNS lymphoma; carcinomatous meningitis; may mimic diffuse white matter disease
B-cell lymphoma; lymphoproliferative disorders; complement cytology
PML if immunocompromised; JCV reactivation in white matter
Neurosyphilis; treatable cause of white matter disease
Bacterial meningitis if acute presentation with fever

Essential Studies.item: MRI brain with/without contrast (including FLAIR, DWI, T1, T2, SWI/GRE)
Essential Studies.timing: Immediate if acute presentation; within 1-2 weeks outpatient
Essential Studies.target: Characterize distribution (periventricular, subcortical, confluent, posterior fossa), symmetry, enhancement pattern, restricted diffusion, microbleeds; Fazekas grading for CSVD
Essential Studies.contraindications: MRI-incompatible devices; severe claustrophobia; renal impairment (gadolinium concern)

Essential Studies.timing: Only if MRI not immediately available or contraindicated
Essential Studies.target: Hypodense white matter; rule out hemorrhage, mass effect, hydrocephalus; less sensitive than MRI for white matter disease

Essential Studies.timing: If vascular etiology suspected; young patient with CSVD pattern
Essential Studies.target: Intracranial stenosis; vasculitis (beading/irregularity); dissection; moyamoya pattern

Extended Studies.timing: Within 1-2 weeks; if spinal cord symptoms present
Extended Studies.target: Spinal cord lesions (MS, NMOSD, B12 deficiency); dorsal column signal in B12 deficiency; longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis in NMOSD

Extended Studies.timing: If metabolic or mitochondrial etiology suspected
Extended Studies.target: Elevated lactate (mitochondrial); elevated choline (active demyelination); reduced NAA (neuronal loss); specific metabolite patterns for leukodystrophies

Extended Studies.timing: If vasculitis suspected and non-invasive imaging inconclusive
Extended Studies.target: Beading, irregularity of medium/small vessels; vessel wall thickening; confirms CNS vasculitis
Extended Studies.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal impairment; coagulopathy; arterial access complications

Extended Studies.timing: If vasculitis or intracranial atherosclerosis suspected
Extended Studies.target: Concentric vessel wall enhancement (vasculitis) vs eccentric (atherosclerosis); inflammatory changes

Extended Studies.timing: If seizures, encephalopathy, or subclinical status suspected
Extended Studies.target: Focal or generalized slowing; epileptiform activity; subclinical seizures

Extended Studies.timing: If MS suspected; subclinical optic nerve involvement
Extended Studies.target: Prolonged P100 latency suggesting prior optic neuritis (supports MS diagnosis)

Extended Studies.timing: If peripheral neuropathy coexists; leukodystrophy with PNS involvement
Extended Studies.target: Peripheral demyelination supports leukodystrophy (MLD, Krabbe, AMN); combined central and peripheral demyelination

Rare/Specialized.timing: If CNS lymphoma, neurosarcoidosis, or vasculitis suspected
Rare/Specialized.target: Hypermetabolic lesions (lymphoma); inflammatory foci; helps guide biopsy
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Pregnancy; uncontrolled diabetes affecting FDG uptake

Rare/Specialized.target: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy; pulmonary infiltrates supporting systemic sarcoidosis

Rare/Specialized.timing: If CADASIL suspected clinically; less invasive than genetic testing
Rare/Specialized.target: Granular osmiophilic material (GOM) deposits in arteriolar walls; NOTCH3 extracellular domain accumulation
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Coagulopathy; skin infection at biopsy site

Rare/Specialized.timing: MS evaluation (optic nerve involvement); Fabry (cornea verticillata); Susac syndrome (branch retinal artery occlusions)
Rare/Specialized.target: RNFL thinning (MS); cornea verticillata (Fabry); branch retinal artery occlusions (Susac)

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily for 3-5 days; infuse over 1 hour; follow with oral prednisone taper if needed (60 mg x 5 days then taper over 2 weeks)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for white matter disease characterization, differential diagnosis, and longitudinal management
Neuroradiology review for MRI pattern interpretation (distribution, symmetry, enhancement, microbleed pattern) to guide differential diagnosis
Rheumatology consultation if autoimmune etiology suspected (SLE, vasculitis, antiphospholipid syndrome, sarcoidosis)
Infectious disease consultation if infectious etiology suspected (HIV, syphilis, PML, other CNS infections)
Genetics consultation for suspected hereditary leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL, leukodystrophy, mitochondrial disease, Fabry disease) in young patients without vascular risk factors
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, and fall prevention given white matter disease affecting motor pathways
Occupational therapy for ADL assessment, adaptive strategies for cognitive and motor deficits, and home safety evaluation
Speech therapy for cognitive-linguistic assessment and swallowing evaluation if bulbar/subcortical white matter involvement
Neuropsychology referral for formal cognitive assessment, baseline documentation, and rehabilitation planning in vascular cognitive impairment
Social work consult for caregiver support, community resources, insurance navigation, and long-term care planning
Cardiology referral for cardiac source evaluation if embolic pattern suspected (echocardiogram, Holter monitor, cardiac MRI)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for sudden new weakness, numbness, speech difficulty, vision loss, or severe headache, as these may indicate acute stroke or disease progression requiring urgent intervention
Return to ED for new seizure, prolonged confusion, or loss of consciousness, as white matter disease may lower seizure threshold
Take all blood pressure medications as prescribed; uncontrolled hypertension is the strongest modifiable risk factor for worsening white matter disease
Take all diabetes and cholesterol medications as prescribed; vascular risk factor control is essential to prevent progression of white matter changes
Do not stop anti-seizure medications abruptly, as this may provoke seizures; discuss any changes with neurology
Follow-up MRI scans are essential to monitor for progression; do not miss scheduled imaging appointments
Report new cognitive difficulties (memory, word-finding, planning), mood changes, or urinary symptoms to neurology, as these may indicate disease progression
Driving restriction if significant cognitive impairment, seizures, or visual field deficits present; require neurology clearance before resuming driving

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Blood pressure target <130/80 mmHg to slow progression of cerebral small vessel disease and white matter injury; home BP monitoring recommended
Strict glycemic control (HbA1c <7.0%) to reduce microvascular damage contributing to white matter disease progression
Smoking cessation to reduce cerebrovascular risk; provide counseling and pharmacotherapy (nicotine replacement, varenicline, bupropion)
Alcohol limitation to <1 drink/day for women and <2 drinks/day for men; excessive alcohol is neurotoxic and worsens white matter disease
Regular aerobic exercise (150 min/week moderate intensity) to improve cerebrovascular health and reduce vascular risk factors; adapt to physical limitations
Mediterranean or MIND diet to reduce cardiovascular risk and support brain health; emphasize fruits, vegetables, whole grains, fish, olive oil
Sleep hygiene and evaluation for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA); untreated OSA contributes to white matter disease through intermittent hypoxia
Cognitive engagement: reading, puzzles, social interaction, and learning new skills to support cognitive reserve and potentially slow cognitive decline
Fall prevention: home safety evaluation, remove trip hazards, adequate lighting, grab bars in bathroom, assistive devices as needed for gait impairment
Caregiver education on recognizing acute neurological changes, medication management, and when to seek emergency care

differential.features: Most common cause in adults >50; periventricular and deep white matter; symmetric; associated with hypertension, diabetes, aging; Fazekas scale 1-3; lacunar infarcts; microbleeds in basal ganglia/thalamus
differential.tests: MRI (Fazekas grading, microbleed pattern on SWI); vascular risk factor assessment; clinical context; no enhancement

differential.features: Younger onset (20-40); periventricular, juxtacortical, infratentorial, and spinal cord lesions; Dawson fingers; enhancing lesions indicate activity; relapsing-remitting course
differential.tests: MRI (Dawson fingers, ovoid periventricular lesions, spinal cord lesions); CSF oligoclonal bands; VEP; McDonald criteria; age of onset

differential.features: Longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis; area postrema syndrome; periependymal brain lesions; aquaporin-4 antibody positive
differential.tests: Aquaporin-4 antibody; MOG antibody; MRI spine (LETM); brain lesion pattern (periependymal)

differential.features: Immunocompromised host; asymmetric, multifocal subcortical lesions; involves U-fibers; no enhancement (unless IRIS); progressive
differential.tests: CSF JCV PCR; immune status (HIV, immunosuppression history); MRI pattern (subcortical U-fibers, no enhancement)

differential.features: Young-onset (30-50); migraine with aura; mood disturbance; lacunar strokes; anterior temporal pole and external capsule involvement; family history
differential.tests: MRI (anterior temporal pole, external capsule); NOTCH3 gene testing; skin biopsy (GOM deposits); family history

differential.features: Headache; encephalopathy; multifocal strokes and white matter lesions; enhancement may be present; younger age without typical vascular risk factors
differential.tests: MRA/CTA (vessel irregularity); conventional angiography; vessel wall MRI; brain biopsy; ESR/CRP; autoimmune labs

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies (especially facial nerve); leptomeningeal enhancement; hypothalamic involvement; systemic sarcoid findings
differential.tests: Chest CT (hilar lymphadenopathy); serum/CSF ACE; gallium scan or PET; tissue biopsy (non-caseating granulomas)

differential.features: Diffuse symmetric white matter changes; progressive cognitive decline; HIV-positive; no focal lesions typically
differential.tests: HIV testing; CD4 count; MRI (diffuse, symmetric); CSF JCV PCR negative; clinical context

differential.features: History of toxic exposure (heroin inhalation, toluene, chemotherapy, radiation); posterior predominant in some toxins; often symmetric
differential.tests: Exposure history; urine drug screen; carboxyhemoglobin; specific toxin levels; MRI pattern (posterior fossa, cerebellar); clinical history

differential.features: History of cranial radiation; white matter changes in radiation field; may develop months to years after treatment
differential.tests: Radiation treatment history; MRI changes confined to radiation field; timing post-treatment

differential.features: Adult-onset: behavioral/psychiatric changes followed by motor decline; symmetric periventricular white matter disease; peripheral neuropathy
differential.tests: Arylsulfatase A activity; urine sulfatides; NCV/EMG (demyelinating neuropathy); genetic testing

differential.features: X-linked; posterior predominant (cerebral ALD) or spinal cord (AMN); adrenal insufficiency; young men
differential.tests: VLCFA (elevated C26:0); ABCD1 gene testing; adrenal function testing; MRI pattern (posterior predominant)

differential.features: Branch retinal artery occlusions; sensorineural hearing loss; encephalopathy; corpus callosum "snowball" lesions
differential.tests: Fluorescein angiography (BRAO); audiometry; MRI (corpus callosum central lesions); clinical triad

differential.features: Acute onset; hypertension; seizures; posterior-predominant vasogenic edema; reversible
differential.tests: MRI (posterior vasogenic edema, elevated ADC); clinical context (hypertension, eclampsia, immunosuppression); reversibility with treatment

differential.features: Rapid sodium correction history; central pontine and/or extrapontine involvement; acute onset
differential.tests: Sodium correction history; MRI (central pons, basal ganglia); clinical context; timeline

evidence.recommendation: Cerebral small vessel disease is the most common cause of white matter hyperintensities; Fazekas scale grades severity and correlates with cognitive decline
Blood pressure control reduces white matter hyperintensity progression; SPRINT-MIND showed intensive BP control (<120 systolic) reduced WMH volume
White matter hyperintensities independently predict stroke, dementia, and death; Rotterdam Scan Study
MRI with FLAIR is the gold standard for detecting white matter disease; DWI and SWI provide additional diagnostic information for acuity and microbleeds
evidence.source: Defined by AAN Practice Parameters; Defined by STandards for ReportIng Vascular changes on nEuroimaging (STRIVE)

evidence.recommendation: CADASIL is the most common genetic cause of white matter disease; anterior temporal pole and external capsule involvement are characteristic
Donepezil provides modest benefit in vascular cognitive impairment; evidence from randomized controlled trials
Primary CNS vasculitis requires tissue diagnosis; angiography alone has limited sensitivity and specificity

disposition.criteria: Stable neurological exam; no acute etiology requiring inpatient treatment; workup can be completed outpatient; outpatient neurology follow-up arranged within 2-4 weeks; home safe for current functional status

Acute or subacute neurological decline with white matter disease; new diagnosis requiring urgent workup (LP, serial imaging, IV treatments); new seizure requiring monitoring; need for IV steroid therapy or IV antibiotics (neurosyphilis); progressive symptoms with unclear etiology

Severe cerebral edema with herniation risk; status epilepticus; fulminant CNS vasculitis with rapidly declining consciousness; hypertensive emergency with acute end-organ damage; respiratory compromise from brainstem white matter involvement

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for brain biopsy (transfer to center with stereotactic neurosurgery capability); need for conventional cerebral angiography not available at current facility; suspected genetic leukoencephalopathy requiring specialized testing
All patients: initial follow-up 2-4 weeks; repeat MRI per disease-specific protocol; cognitive monitoring q6-12 months; vascular risk factor reassessment at each visit
